items.title: Sudan's paramilitary force agrees to U.S. proposal for humanitarian ceasefire
items.summary_auto: Sudan's paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF) agreed to a proposal from the United States for a humanitarian ceasefire, the group said on Thursday in a statement.

items.title: World Meteorological Organization gives update on state of climate ahead of COP30
items.summary_auto: Officials with the World Meteorological Organization are speaking on Thursday on climate, as world leaders gather in Brazil for the 30th Conference of Parties on climate.

items.title: Cartel-fighting mayor’s assassination in Mexico’s avocado heartland fuels citizen fury
items.summary_auto: Uruapan Mayor Carlos Manzo’s killing triggered a spasm of fury that has fuelled protests across the fertile Mexican state of Michoacan, which produces limes and avocados found on Canadian grocery shelves.

items.title: Israel strikes south Lebanon despite ceasefire, says it’s targeting Hezbollah military sites
items.summary_auto: The Israeli military says it has started a wave of strikes in southern Lebanon Thursday, claiming it is targeting military sites belonging to Hezbollah.

items.title: David Common announced as CBC’s new Morning Live host
items.summary_auto: Veteran reporter and current Metro Morning radio host David Common will replace Heather Hiscox as host of CBC Morning Live, the Crown corporation announced Thursday. The announcement comes on the same day as Hiscox’s final broadcast as host and 20 years after she first took over the position.

items.title: BREAKING | Supreme Court won’t hear appeal in B.C. ostrich case, opening door to controversial cull
Louvre security changes could take until 2032 to address, as damning auditor's report published
items.summary_auto: France's Louvre Museum began a security audit a decade ago but the recommended upgrades will not be completed until 2032, the state auditor said in a report on Thursday compiled before a spectacular heist there last month.

items.title: French auditor's report raps Louvre for excessive art acquisitions even as most rooms lacked cameras
items.summary_auto: France's Louvre Museum began a security audit a decade ago but the recommended upgrades will not be completed until 2032, the state auditor said in a report on Thursday compiled before a spectacular heist there last month.

items.title: Vietnam evacuates hundreds of thousands ahead of Typhoon Kalmaegi, which left 114 dead in Philippines
items.summary_auto: The death toll in the Philippines from Typhoon Kalmaegi rose to 114 with another 127 people still missing, the disaster agency said on Thursday, as the storm that devastated the country's central regions regained strength as it headed towards Vietnam.

items.title: Hereditary cancer, high cholesterol risk for 100,000 Canadians to be checked in genetic screening project
items.summary_auto: Over the the next five years, up to 100,000 people in Ontario will be screened for genetic conditions that increase their risk of hereditary cancers and a condition tied to high cholesterol and heart disease, says Princess Margaret Cancer Centre.

items.title: Here's how much money you needed to make to be among Nova Scotia's top earners
items.summary_auto: New numbers from Statistics Canada reveal how much the highest-income Nova Scotians make. The information is based on tax filings for 2023.

items.title: Did Bill Gates really say we don't need to address climate change?
The budget aims for a permanent School Food Program. But that doesn't mean free lunches for everyone
items.summary_auto: School food advocates welcome the federal budget pledge for a permanent national program with dedicated funding annually. Yet given the current patchwork of offerings in place, experts say there's much work ahead to ensure all kids can access a robust and sustainable food program at school.

items.title: The hidden humans powering the AI economy
items.summary_auto: We usually hear two sides to the AI and employment story: star engineers earning enormous salaries, and job loss for many others. But from gig workers paid poorly to annotate data, to people with advanced degrees training specialized AI, it takes a huge labour force to develop AI.

items.title: Losing hope, he quit the Nunavik police. Years later, many still feel unsupported by the force
items.summary_auto: Johnny Saunders quit his job as a Nunavik police officer 20 years ago. He says the same issues that led to him leave remain unaddressed. Earlier this week, residents held marches across the region to denounce police brutality and an erosion of trust.

items.title: Here's what each federal department plans to cut under Budget 2025
items.summary_auto: Tuesday's federal budget  offers a glimpse into how dozens of government departments plan to rein in spending following this summer's comprehensive expenditure review. Here's a department-by-department breakdown.

items.title: Margaret Atwood on reading palms, getting older — and holding grudges
items.summary_auto: Margaret Atwood’s new memoir Book of Lives explores how the world has shaped her writing, and how that writing in turn shaped her life

items.title: Northwestern Ontario bore brunt of province's wildfire season with evacuations, outages and a record blaze
items.summary_auto: The province's 2025 wildfire season officially ended Friday, with northwestern Ontario experiencing the most activity. The region, with the largest wildfire on record, faced several community evacuations and days-long power outages as Canada experienced its second worst fire season. Officials and community leaders run down what's needed to be prepared for next season.

items.title: #TheMoment a huge inflatable pumpkin went rogue
items.summary_auto: Katie Morgan tells The National about the moment she saved her giant inflatable pumpkin from blowing away in the wind.

items.title: U.S. government shutdown to force air traffic reductions starting Friday
items.summary_auto: The U.S. Federal Aviation Administration said Wednesday that it was taking the extraordinary step of reducing air traffic by 10 per cent across 40 "high-volume" U.S. markets beginning Friday morning to maintain travel safety as air traffic controllers exhibit signs of strain during the ongoing government shutdown.

items.title: Sask. uranium company says White House won't meddle in its core business under U.S. reactor deal
items.summary_auto: The chief executive of Saskatchewan-based Cameco Corp. wants to make clear that the U.S. government is not getting involved in its main uranium mining business under a massive nuclear reactor deal announced last week.

items.title: Will Canada actually join Eurovision? Not without some challenges, experts say
items.summary_auto: Yesterday's budget teased that the government is working with CBC/Radio-Canada to explore Canada's participation in the Eurovision Song Contest. While Europop fans might be excited, Canadian participation might not be so easy, as past attempts have proved.

items.title: Pressure grows on Quebec to force an end to Montreal transit strikes
items.summary_auto: A coalition of business groups is calling on the Quebec government to take action to end the ongoing transit strikes. The workers are accusing the business leaders of only looking out for their profits at the expense of workers’ rights.

items.title: Indigenous leaders decry budget’s lack of money for key reconciliation programs
items.summary_auto: Indigenous leaders are concerned after this year’s federal budget left key reconciliation programs without guaranteed money beyond spring 2026. Programs covering education, health and urban Indigenous friendship centres are running out of money, prompting fears they could be terminated or face massive cuts.

items.title: Tracking Trump’s changes to law enforcement
items.summary_auto: It’s been one year since U.S. President Donald Trump’s second election win. CBC’s Mike Crawley breaks down how Trump’s policies have affected law enforcement and immigration since his return to the White House.

items.title: Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum presses charges after man eludes security, gropes her
items.summary_auto: Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum said on Wednesday that she had filed a criminal complaint against a man who groped and tried to kiss her as she greeted members of the public, a day after a video of the incident went viral.

items.title: Carney's budget needs 2 more votes. Here's the local funding that could get it passed
items.summary_auto: With one MP already crossing the floor to join the Liberals, Prime Minister Mark Carney now needs only two more votes, or abstentions, to pass his budget. And there is some local funding that opposition MPs might find hard to resist.
